property.name: text
property.value:
This SDF model illustrates the use of numerical synthesis for fast prototyping. In this model, we hope to create an FSMActor as a controller that can, based on the requirement of clients, grant the resource. However, it is forbidden that the controller grants two clients simultaneously. The overall requirement can be concretized by the following specification. Also, whether Client1 wants the resource is based on comparing values produced from two sensors.
ALWAYS (X+Y>3 -> NEXT (grant1)) ALWAYS (X^2+Y^2<4 -> NEXT (grant2)) ALWAYS (!(grant1 && grant2))
INPUT req1, req2 OUTPUT grant1, grant2
In this example, when we take X+Y>3 and X^2+Y^2<4 as two independent boolean input variables req1 and req2, we are unable to find a controller, as it is possible to have (req1, req2) = (true, true).
However, we can check the invalidty of this counter strategy using JBernstein (http://www6.in.tum.de/~chengch/efsmt/jbernstein.html) \forall x, y \in [0, 4]: !(X+Y>3 && X^2+Y^2<4), which is equivalent to \forall x, y \in [0, 4]: X+Y>3 -> X^2+Y^2>=4, a format that can be checked by JBernstein JBernstein returns true.
Therefore, this counter strategy is impossible to be realized. We can add the following to the specification, based on the proporgated result from the theory: "ASSUME (ALWAYS !(req1 && req2))". When we rerun the synthesis engine, we can have a controller.

property.name: text
property.value:
Instructions to synthesize the FSMActor automatically: (1) Save the specification as a separate text file. (2) On the menu bar, choose "Import -> Import FSMActor using synthesis". A file selection dialog will appear. Select the text file from step 1. (3) Select either Co-Buechi or Buechi solver. For Co-Buechi solver, select unroll step to be 1.
Specification: NumericalLTLOriginal.txt is the abstract spec. NumericalLTLRefined.txt is the refined spec by considering the spurious counter-strategy. NumericalJBernstein.txt is the file to be checked by JBernstein

property.name: text
property.value: Numerical LTL synthesis for cyber-physical systems

property.name: text
property.value:
This model illustrates the use of numerical synthesis for rapid prototyping. In this model, the Controller is automatically synthesized from requirements. Specifically, the Controller regulates access to a shared resource. Based on two sensor inputs, the Contoller is required to grant access one iteration later to at most one of the requesters according to the following requirements:
ALWAYS (X+Y>3 -> NEXT (grant1)) ALWAYS (X^2+Y^2<4 -> NEXT (grant2)) ALWAYS (! (grant1 && grant2))

property.name: text
property.value:
This example illustrates why using numerical values rather than just booleans is important. Specifically, if we take req1=(X+Y>3) and req2=(X^2+Y^2<4) as two independent boolean input variables, then we will be unable to find a controller, as it is possible to have (req1, req2) = (true, true).
The synthesis tool used here checks the invalidty of this counter strategy using JBernstein (http://www6.in.tum.de/~chengch/efsmt/jbernstein.html) Specifically it verifies that the following assertion holds:
\forall x, y \in [0, 4]: !(X+Y > 3 && X^2+Y^2 < 4)
which is equivalent to
\forall x, y \in [0, 4]: X+Y>3 => X^2+Y^2>=4
a format that can be checked by JBernstein. Knowing that this counter strategy cannot be realized, we add the following to the specification:
ASSUME (ALWAYS !(req1 && req2))
When we rerun the synthesis engine, we can have a controller.

property.name: text
property.value:
Notice: G4LTL has an academic version that allows to perform numerical LTL synthesis automatically (available upon request).
To use it, simply replace g4ltl.jar in ptII/lib by the academic version. Then during synthesis, the solver will ask to provide the theory template.

entity.name: X
entity.doc: Create a sequence of uniformly distributed random numbers

entity.name: Y
entity.doc: Create a sequence of uniformly distributed random numbers

property.name: guardExpression
property.value: ((req1 == true) && (req2 == false)) || ((req1 == false) && (req2 == false)) || ((req1 == false) && (req2 == true)) || ((req1 == true) && (req2 == true))
